segments.text: "Around that time an ambitious young New York reporter shows up at Gatsby’s door on his day off. The man, having heard whispers of Gatsby’s name connected with mysterious events, is determined to get a statement from him. Meanwhile, rumors swirl about Gatsby’s past, including fantastic legends like an underground pipeline to Canada and even tales of him living in a boat that looks like a house.",

"After a confused five minutes of back-and-forth, it becomes clear that the reporter’s vague understanding of Gatsby’s reputation was enough to prompt his visit. Over the summer, Gatsby’s notoriety grew as hundreds who had enjoyed his hospitality spread legends about his mysterious past.",
"narrative clarity with a hint of mystery" } }, {

"We learn that James Gatz – the name he was born with back in North Dakota – transformed himself into Jay Gatsby, a persona conceived from his youthful dreams. As a young man, he had already pictured himself as a son of God, destined to serve a vast, lavish, and even vulgar beauty.",

"For over a year, he labored along the south shore of Lake Superior, eking out a living as a clam-digger, salmon-fisher, or any other role that met his basic needs. By night, his mind erupted in a turbulent riot of fantastical dreams, hinting at an unreality beneath the everyday world.",
"variable – quiet in the labor description and more rapid in the dream description",
"thoughtful pauses before turning to the fantastical imagery",

"An instinct for his future glory led him briefly to a small Lutheran college in southern Minnesota, only to find the institution indifferent to his destiny. Fate, however, intervened when Dan Cody’s yacht anchored near where young Gatz was adrift on Lake Superior.",
"evenly paced with a hint of building suspense",

"To young Gatz, the yacht symbolized all the beauty and glamour in the world. Dan Cody, a rugged fifty-year-old adventurer of mining fortunes and boozy escapades, soon took an interest in him. In a few days, Cody not only renamed him Jay Gatsby but also outfitted him with lavish attire—a blue coat, white duck trousers, and a yachting cap—sending the young man on a course that would define his life.",

"Over the following years, Gatsby served Cody in numerous capacities—from steward to skipper. Although Cody’s legacy included a tangled legacy of money and mishaps (notably involving Ella Kaye and dangerous parties at sea), for Gatsby it was a crucible in which his identity was forged. He barely understood the legal devices that prevented him from receiving Cody’s money, yet the experience endowed him with an education and ambition befitting the man he had dreamed of becoming.",

"Later, as I (Nick Carraway) reflect on these early revelations, I realize that Gatsby’s origins were far more complex than the wild rumors suggested. Though I had believed both everything and nothing about him at different times, I now use this quiet interlude to set the record straight.",

"Shortly thereafter, I began spending more time at Gatsby’s house. One Sunday afternoon, barely two minutes into my visit, a party formed as Tom Buchanan was unexpectedly brought in for a drink. Alongside him were a man named Sloane and a charming woman, both arriving on horseback.",
"strategic pauses to underscore shifts in the scene",
"I'm delighted to see you. I'm delighted that you dropped in. Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar. I’ll have something to drink for you in just a minute.",
"earnest, concealing his unease about Tom's unexpected presence",
"gruffly polite, with a note of superiority",
"I believe we’ve met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan. I know your wife.",
"a measured pause to let the implication sink in",
"Oh, yes. We did meet. I remember very well… About two weeks ago—you were with Nick here.",
"steady, with an undercurrent of smug assurance",
"We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby. What do you say?",
"Neutral American with a hint of Southern charm",
"Certainly; I’d be delighted to have you. Please, don’t hurry—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other guests from New York drop in.",
"eager yet somewhat forced in his politeness",

"As the party unfolds, conversation turns to matters of celebrity and scandal. Tom smirks over comments about guests and famous faces. At one point, Daisy’s voice sparkles as she remarks on a gorgeous woman under a white-plum tree, noting that even the man directing her attention seems to be an acquaintance from a long-forgotten film.",
"These things excite me so. If you want to kiss me any time this evening, Nick, just mention my name—or even present a green card. I'm giving out green—",
"natural pauses that highlight her playful banter",
"Look around, Daisy. You must see the faces of many people you've only heard about.",

"Later that evening, as twilight gives way to night, conversations grow more intimate and confessions more weighted. Amid the sparkling crowd at Gatsby’s party, the pervasive feeling of superficial gaiety begins to crack as deeper, unresolved emotions surface—especially for Gatsby himself, whose heart feels further and further from the woman he adores.",
"She didn’t like it. She didn’t have a good time.",
"I wouldn’t ask too much of her. I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before. She’ll see.",

"In a final, almost dreamlike flashback, Gatsby recalls an autumn night five years past—a time when the falling leaves and the moonlit sidewalk formed a secret ladder between worlds. In that evocative darkness, his kiss with Daisy sealed the union of his transcendent dreams with the fragile reality of her mortal breath; an ineffable moment that rendered his inner life both immortal and eternally out of reach.",
"slow and deliberate, as if savoring every word",
"long, reflective pauses that draw out the imagery",
